entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Chan-05
entry.itemBody: Management of a price-weighted index most likely entails:

answerFeedback.19b9641d-261f-4fae-a9c7-f0c37564c195: Incorrect because price-weighted indexes are not rebalanced because the weight of each constituent security is determined by its price.
answerFeedback.363251d6-a0d7-4e24-bb1e-f48edf9827d5: Incorrect because price-weighted indexes are not rebalanced because the weight of each constituent security is determined by its price.
answerFeedback.bd46ee42-10fd-469e-a0e6-4843dbd1814e: Correct because price-weighted indexes are not rebalanced because the weight of each constituent security is determined by its price. Reconstitution is the process of changing the constituent securities in an index.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04395
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements best describes hedge fund indexes?

answerFeedback.03e57d91-d09a-427c-98b5-50942f62df90: Correct because frequently, a hedge fund reports its performance to only one database. The result is little overlap of funds covered by the different indices. With little overlap between their constituents, different global hedge funds indices may reflect very different performance for the hedge fund industry over the same period of time.
answerFeedback.16b9d1c0-4fe8-4cd3-b1f6-f15ae9819e16: Incorrect because as unregulated entities hedge funds are not required to report their performance. This means a hedge fund index is unlikely to be composed of regulated entities.
answerFeedback.8a229816-6180-4bda-b2df-44d95dfad283: Incorrect because a consequence of the voluntary performance reporting is the potential for survivorship bias.

choices.itemBody: B. Potential survivorship bias is reduced by voluntary performance reporting
C. There may be little overlap in index constituents between different indexes offered by different index providers

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Equity-Bailey-10
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a market-capitalization-weighted index and one of its four constituent stocks:

  Total Market Capitalization (in $ Billions)
Stock 20
Index 57

If the stock price is $30 per share and the index value is 100, the stock's weight in the index is closest to:

answerFeedback.0324869e-fad9-4c00-872a-c4091b5d5262: Incorrect because this is the stock's weight using the price-weighted method: stock's price / index value = $30 / 100 = 30%.
answerFeedback.1b26f12a-c382-4cbe-b046-3f45bba56aaa: Incorrect because 25% is the stock's weight using equal-weighted method: 1 stock / 4 stocks = 25%.
answerFeedback.5eb93fb3-ea65-491d-b12c-f400d74b3d69: Correct because the stock's weight in a market-capitalization-weighted index = market capitalization of stock / market capitalization of index = $20 billion / $57 billion = 35.08%, which is closest to 35%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05200
entry.itemBody: Security market indices most likely serve as proxies for:

answerFeedback.2902ab5c-ba64-4dea-9039-ae5064bd1485: Incorrect because security market indices do not serve as proxies for measuring nonsystematic risk. Nonsystematic risk is risk that is local or limited to a particular asset or industry that need not affect assets outside of that asset class. Investors are capable of avoiding nonsystematic risk through diversification by forming a portfolio of assets that are not highly correlated with one another. Security market indices are usually broad and well diversified. They do serve as market proxies when measuring risk-adjusted performance. The beta of an actively managed portfolio allows investors to form a passive alternative with the same level of systematic risk.
answerFeedback.345d7a6b-a42c-4573-8b33-14500c05d314: Incorrect because asset-based valuation is a method for valuing individual companies, so a broad security market indices is not a useful proxy. Asset-based valuation of a company uses estimates of the market or fair value of the company's assets and liabilities. Asset-based valuation models are frequently used together with multiplier models to value private companies. As public companies increase reporting or disclosure of fair values, asset-based valuation may be increasingly used to supplement present value and multiplier models of valuation.
answerFeedback.5de0fe6a-bca3-41f8-9848-2a84279c8718: Correct because indices play a critical role as proxies for asset classes in asset allocation models.

choices.itemBody: B. asset classes in asset allocation models.
C. the fair value of assets in asset-based valuation models.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10034
entry.itemBody: A multi-market index is most appropriately used as a benchmark:

answerFeedback.02a5805c-bc31-4ee7-9091-5d903e58e091: Incorrect because a small cap growth index is a style index, not a multi-market index.
answerFeedback.b4932856-71df-45b8-870b-62c599c06745: Correct because indexes also serve as market proxies when measuring risk-adjusted performance. The beta of an actively managed portfolio allows investors to form a passive alternative with the same level of systematic risk. In this case, multi-market indexes usually comprise indexes from different countries would serve as benchmarks to calculate beta for the portfolios of global stock managers.
answerFeedback.fee5f70b-633b-4141-8214-14c41f52cf58: Incorrect because multi-market indexes usually comprise indexes from different countries and are designed to represent multiple security markets. Multi-market indexes may represent multiple national markets, geographic regions, economic development groups, and, in some cases, the entire world. A multi-market index would not be used as a benchmark for a single country ETF.

choices.itemBody: B. for a small-capitalization growth stock manager.
C. to calculate beta for the portfolio of a global stock manager.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Equity 07RPG
entry.itemBody: A world equity index is most likely considered a:

answerFeedback.592001ec-0d84-49cc-a907-5b052252201d: Incorrect because style indexes represent groups of securities classified according to market capitalization, value, growth, or a combination of these characteristics. They are intended to reflect the investing styles of certain investors, such as the growth investor, value investor, and small-cap investor.
answerFeedback.6b68b56f-e02a-45ca-a5fa-b6b6f3acec27: Incorrect because sector indexes represent and track different economic sectors—such as consumer goods, energy, finance, health care, and technology—on either a national, regional, or global basis. A world equity index most likely does not represent a specific economic sector.
answerFeedback.db6fa37f-cea7-4061-aaa8-8456695de5ba: Correct because multi-market indexes usually comprise indexes from different countries and regions and are designed to represent multiple security markets. Multi-market indexes may represent multiple national markets, geographic regions, economic development groups, and, in some cases, the entire world. World indexes are of importance to investors who take a global approach to equity investing without any particular bias toward a particular country or region.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08624
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a security index:

Period Return (%)
1 12
2 −8
3 2

If the index's value is 100 at the beginning of Period 1, the index's value at the end of Period 3 is closest to:

answerFeedback.5d80c389-72fa-4345-9182-8fdd9c79c128: Incorrect because the value of the index at the end of Period 2, not Period 3 = Beginning value × (1 + Period 1 return) × (1 + Period 2 return) = 100 × (100 + 12%) × (100 – 8%) = 103.04, which is closest to 103.
answerFeedback.b13839af-fc9f-4420-aec0-8ca4aceb1ca6: Incorrect because returns for the three periods are added, not compounded: Beginning value + (100 × Period 1 return) + (100 × Period 2 return) + (100 × Period 3 return) = 100 + (100 × 12%) + (100 × – 8%) + (100 × 2%) = 100 + 12 – 8 + 2 = 106.
answerFeedback.c4890dc8-1d5f-424e-b502-c1bb400f8b80: Correct because it is the value of the index at the end of Period 3 = Beginning value × (1+Period 1 return) × (1 + Period 2 return) × (1 + Period 3 return) = 100 × (100 + 12%) × (100 – 8%) × (1 + 2%) ≈ 105.10, which is closest to 105.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01133
entry.itemBody: The beginning value for an index is 1540 and the ending value is 1575. If the income for the period is 55, the total return of the index is closest to:

answerFeedback.6d3b726f-6420-4ef7-bbfd-7fa4b03b636f: Correct because the total return of an index is the price appreciation, or change in the value of the price return index, plus income (dividends and/or interest) over the period, expressed as a percentage of the beginning value of the price return index. Total return = (ending index value – beginning index value + income) / beginning index value = (1575 – 1540 + 55) / 1540 = 90 / 1540 = 5.8%.
answerFeedback.7276be09-6662-403f-b6b4-fbb337313428:
Incorrect because the income is not taken into account:

(1575–1540) / 1540 = 35 / 1540 = 2.2%.
answerFeedback.84acde44-60cc-4145-8d3c-943204f7515d:
Incorrect because the beginning and ending index values were reversed in the calculation:

(1540 – 1575 + 55) / 1575 = 20 / 1575 = 1.3%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10319
entry.itemBody: Fixed-income indexes most likely:

answerFeedback.17ebbba7-155a-4ea1-a181-301a40ffdd94: Incorrect because it is difficult, compared with equity indexes, for investors to replicate fixed-income indexes and duplicate their performance.
answerFeedback.b0136c69-816a-4a1e-8da8-928b014b8d98: Incorrect because the number of fixed-income securities is many times larger than the number of equity securities.
answerFeedback.f85d854c-d77e-4f52-bb01-29c0e589e53e: Correct because compared to equity indexes, fixed-income index providers must contact dealers to obtain current prices on constituent securities to update the index or they must estimate the prices of constituent securities using the prices of traded fixed-income securities with similar characteristics.

choices.itemBody: A. are more easily replicated than equity indexes.
B. require the provider to estimate the prices of some constituent securities.
C. are created from a smaller universe of possible constituent securities than the universe of equity securities.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Equity-Bailey-02
entry.itemBody: As time passes after inception, the value of the price version of an index is:

answerFeedback.49b0cf2b-b8dc-4679-a2bc-0885ab70a5f7: Correct because at inception, the values of the price and total return versions of an index are equal. As time passes, however, the value of the total return index will exceed the value of the price return index.
answerFeedback.9567f139-5cb9-4153-a35c-87370e97a984: Incorrect because at inception, the values of the price and total return versions of an index are equal. As time passes, however, the value of the total return index will exceed the value of the price return index.
answerFeedback.e490d457-e756-4b23-b091-596ce8b3c246: Incorrect because at inception, the values of the price and total return versions of an index are equal. As time passes, however, the value of the total return index will exceed the value of the price return index.

choices.itemBody: A. less than the value of the total return version.
B. equal to the value of the total return version.
C. greater than the value of the total return version.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Equity-Elkinawy-Young-01
entry.itemBody: A disadvantage of an equal-weighted index is that:

answerFeedback.3193a979-fffa-4d7a-9c79-6e880c26811b: Correct because this is considered a disadvantage of an equal weighted index. Equal weighting has a number of disadvantages. Securities that constitute the largest fraction of the target market value are underrepresented, and securities that constitute a small fraction of the target market value are overrepresented.
answerFeedback.44f01113-b701-45f4-b0be-0d200156b04e: Incorrect because smaller stocks are overrepresented in an equal weighted index. Equal weighting has a number of disadvantages. Securities that constitute the largest fraction of the target market value are underrepresented, and securities that constitute a small fraction of the target market value are overrepresented.
answerFeedback.c1810c7c-b707-46df-b123-f9f9fa814485: Incorrect because an equal weighted index requires frequent rebalancing, not reconstitution, when its constituent securities’ prices change. Equal weighting has a number of disadvantages. After the index is constructed and the prices of constituent securities change, the index is no longer equally weighted. Therefore, maintaining equal weights requires frequent adjustments (rebalancing) to the index.

choices.itemBody: A. maintaining equal weights requires frequent reconstitution of the index.
B. securities that represent a relatively large fraction of the target market value are underrepresented.
C. securities that represent a relatively small fraction of the target market value are underrepresented.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Equity-Crutu-08
entry.itemBody: An increase in shares held by controlling shareholders most likely impacts the constituent weightings of a(n):

answerFeedback.6ea237ea-fe7f-4052-9dff-878326f76e51: Incorrect because in price weighting, the weight on each constituent security is determined by dividing its price by the sum of all the prices of the constituent securities, which means the lower free float (due to increased weight of controlling shareholders) has no impact on constituent weights.
answerFeedback.c0d6cb56-099b-49db-96df-13ddebd2ce63: Correct because float-adjusted market-capitalization-weighted indexes reflect the shares available for public trading (excluding the ones held by controlling shareholders) by multiplying the market price per share by the number of shares available to the investing public (i.e., the float-adjusted market capitalization), which means constituent weights are impacted.
answerFeedback.eaf8cc42-de88-4b30-abe2-0956589c101d: Incorrect because the equal weighting assigns an equal weight to each constituent security at inception, which means the lower free float (due to increased number of shares held by controlling shareholders) has no impact on constituent weights.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-00777
entry.itemBody: Equity style indexes most likely represent groups of securities classified by:

answerFeedback.1afc1300-50ee-41ab-ab33-5d288c5496c3: Correct because style indices represent groups of securities classified according to market capitalization, value, growth, or a combination of these characteristics. They are intended to reflect the investing styles of certain investors, such as the growth investor, value investor, and small-cap investor.
answerFeedback.209d8fb5-0293-4050-945c-fa9f34c5273f: Incorrect because geography and sector might be combined in a sector index, but neither characteristic, either on its own or in combination, is likely to be used to construct a style index.
answerFeedback.645705ff-867d-4148-9dab-38ca90737d37: Incorrect because asset class and GDP weight might be combined in a multi-market index, but neither characteristic is likely to be used to construct a style index.

choices.itemBody: C. asset class and gross domestic product (GDP) weight.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09526
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about an equal-weighted index composed of three stocks:

Stock Beginning-of-Period Price End-of-Period Price
1 $10 $8
2 $20 $24
3 $30 $30

If there is a 2% return from dividends for each of the three stocks, the total return of the index is:

answerFeedback.5e812297-fd25-487e-873d-e3c93d1daf34: Correct because total return measures price appreciation plus interest, dividends, and other distributions. Thus, the total return of an index is the price appreciation, or change in the value of the price return index, plus income (dividends and/or interest) over the period, expressed as a percentage of the beginning value of the price return index. Price return for Stock 1 = ($8 – $10) / $10 = –0.20 = –20%. Total return = price return + dividends = –20% + 2% = –18%. Price return for Stock 2 = ($24 – $20) / $20 = 0.20 = 20%. Total return = 20% + 2% = 22%. Price return for Stock 3 = ($30 – $30) / $30 = 0.00 = 0%. Total return = 0% + 2% = 2%. The total return of the index = (–18% + 22% + 2%) / 3 = 6% / 3 = 2%.
answerFeedback.c82d8fdb-2933-4061-85da-7b1b26378c52: Incorrect because dividends are not accounted for. It is simply the price return of the index. Price return for Stock 1 = ($8 – $10) / $10 = –0.20 = –20%. Price return for Stock 2 = ($24 – $20) / $20 = 0.20 = 20%. Price return for Stock 3 = ($30 – $30) / $30 = 0.00 = 0%. The price return of the index = –20% + 20% + 0% = 0% / 3 = 0%.
answerFeedback.d3cb3ebd-4ed2-45f0-854b-86e502c18f5b: Incorrect because dividends are not accounted for. It is simply the price return of the index. Price return for Stock 1 = ($8 – $10) / $10 = –0.20 = –20%. Price return for Stock 2 = ($24 – $20) / $20 = 0.20 = 20%. Price return for Stock 3 = ($30 – $30) / $30 = 0.00 = 0%. The price return of the index = –20% + 20% + 0% = 0% / 3 = 0%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06681
entry.itemBody: Over time, which of the following indexes most likely has portfolio weights that shift away from securities that have increased in relative value and toward securities that have fallen in relative value? A:

answerFeedback.0988c581-31c1-46be-b525-d8147e754ffd: Correct because fundamentally weighted indexes generally will have a contrarian 'effect' in that the portfolio weights will shift away from securities that have increased in relative value and toward securities that have fallen in relative value whenever the portfolio is rebalanced.
answerFeedback.1a419d85-ca05-4139-98be-f0c6f575ca05: Incorrect because a market capitalization weighting method leads to overweighting stocks that have risen in price (and may be overvalued) and underweighting stocks that have declined in price (and may be undervalued). The effect of this weighting method is similar to a momentum investment strategy in that over time, the securities that have risen in price the most will have the largest weights in the index.
answerFeedback.810405e2-d7d2-4255-bf2f-967acad5ee2d: Incorrect because the main disadvantage of price weighting is that it results in arbitrary weights for each security. It does not have a contrarian effect.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10904
entry.itemBody: Which of the following indexes is composed of futures contracts?

answerFeedback.2ab3145d-0d3f-40ca-8bc4-ea49ca7c0037: Correct because commodity indexes consist of futures contracts on one or more commodities.
answerFeedback.444886db-b656-41f0-a7ff-7d53bdccc0ef: Incorrect because hedge fund indexes reflect the returns on hedge funds. Hedge funds are private investment vehicles that typically use leverage and long and short investment strategies. A number of research organizations maintain databases of hedge fund returns and summarize these returns into indexes. Although the underlying hedge funds may contain futures contracts, the indexes are not comprised of futures contracts.
answerFeedback.a954758b-a964-41e6-b857-2434ee50b091: Incorrect because a broad equity market index, as its name suggests, represents an entire given equity market and typically includes securities representing more than 90 percent of the selected market. Although the underlying securities may include contracts, the index is not comprised of futures contracts.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02846
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about an index and one security in the index:

  Security Index
Price €38.00 ---
Shares outstanding 540 million ---
Sum of the prices of all constituent securities --- €808.50
Sum of the market caps of all constituent securities --- €420 billion
Number of constituent securities --- 18

Which of the following index-weighting methods most likely gives this security the greatest weight in the index?

answerFeedback.07912ba1-5ba0-4ce4-8b3b-2b9a8ea47e99:
Correct because equal weighting results in the largest weight:

Equal weight = 1 / number of constituent securities = 1 / 18 = 5.6%.

Price weight = price of security / sum of all prices of constituent securities = 38 / 808.50 = 4.7%.

Market cap weight = price × shares outstanding / sum of all market caps of constituent securities = €38 × 540m / €420b = €20.52b / €420b ≈ 4.9%.

Alternatively, B is correct because the security's price is less than the average price of the securities in the index and the security's market cap is less than the average market cap of the securities in the index:

Index's average price = sum of all prices of constituent securities / number of constituent securities = €808.50 / 18 ≈ €44.92 > security's price of  €38.00.

Index's average market cap = sum of all market caps of constituent securities / number of constituent securities =€420b / 18 = €23.3b > security's market cap of €20.52b (€38.00 × 540mm). The mathematical fact that both these averages are greater than the price and market cap of the individual security means equal weight must be the correct answer.
answerFeedback.bc830b23-2596-4660-851a-25586a18c9f8:
Incorrect because equal weighting results in the largest weight:

Equal weight = 1 / number of constituent securities = 1 / 18 = 5.6%.

Price weight = price of security / sum of all prices of constituent securities = 38 / 808.50 = 4.7%.

Market cap weight = price × shares outstanding / sum of all market caps of constituent securities = €38 × 540m / €420b = €20.52b / €420b ≈ 4.9%.
answerFeedback.fae471eb-fb4b-4405-bb50-d249cbe74a2e:
Incorrect because equal weighting results in the largest weight:

Equal weight = 1 / number of constituent securities = 1 / 18 = 5.6%.

Price weight = price of security / sum of all prices of constituent securities = 38 / 808.50 = 4.7%.

Market cap weight = price × shares outstanding / sum of all market caps of constituent securities = €38 × 540m / €420b = €20.52b / €420b ≈ 4.9%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Equity-Crutu-12
entry.itemBody: Reconstitution of a security index is best described as the process of changing the:

answerFeedback.6f98d362-63db-4f29-a579-f4202b941c44: Incorrect because rebalancing (not reconstitution) refers to adjusting the weights of the constituent securities in the index.
answerFeedback.bf894213-da09-4a55-b23b-71830f6f296f: Correct because reconstitution is the process of changing the constituent securities in an index.
answerFeedback.ec4bc737-de90-481b-beab-303a95d71202: Incorrect because the reconstitution date (not the reconstitution process) is the date on which index providers review the constituent securities, re-apply the initial criteria for inclusion in the index, and select which securities to retain, remove, or add.

choices.itemBody: B. weights of the constituent securities in the index.
C. date on which the index provider reviews the constituent securities.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Equity-Fairborn-03
entry.itemBody: A total return index reflects:

answerFeedback.4f9a11ec-e872-4194-9f85-e89752b43db2: Correct, because a total return index, in contrast, reflects not only the prices of the constituent securities but also the reinvestment of all income received since inception.
answerFeedback.e15714a9-2e20-4ed1-9824-dc55a9feb3c6: Incorrect, because a total return index, in contrast, reflects not only the prices of the constituent securities but also the reinvestment of all income received since inception.
answerFeedback.e56aabbd-429a-4b56-acc7-eeffe2345224: Incorrect, because a total return index, in contrast, reflects not only the prices of the constituent securities but also the reinvestment of all income received since inception.

choices.itemBody: A. only the prices of constituent securities.
B. only the reinvestment of all income received since index inception.
C. both the prices of constituent securities and the reinvestment of all income received since index inception.

entry.title: CFA0162-Q1

feedback.neutral: C is correct. A security market index represents the value of a given security market, market segment, or asset class.

entry.itemBody: A security market index represents the:

choices.itemBody: A. risk of a security market.
B. security market as a whole.
C. security market, market segment, or asset class.

entry.title: CFA0162-Q4

feedback.neutral: C is correct. The difference between a price return index and a total return index consisting of identical securities and weights is the income generated over time by the underlying securities. If the securities in the index do not generate income, both indexes will be identical in value.

entry.itemBody: One month after inception, the price return version and total return version of a single index (consisting of identical securities and weights) will be equal if:

choices.itemBody: A. market prices have not changed.
B. capital gains are offset by capital losses.
C. the securities do not pay dividends or interest.

entry.title: CFA0162-Q5

feedback.neutral: A is correct. At inception, the values of the price return and total return versions of an index are equal.

entry.itemBody: The values of a price return index and a total return index consisting of identical equal-weighted dividend-paying equities will be equal:

choices.itemBody: B. at inception and on rebalancing dates.
C. at inception and on reconstitution dates.

entry.title: CFA0162-Q2

feedback.neutral: A is correct. Security market indexes are constructed and managed like a portfolio of securities.

entry.itemBody: Security market indexes are:

choices.itemBody: A. constructed and managed like a portfolio of securities.
B. simple interchangeable tools for measuring the returns of different asset classes.
C. valued on a regular basis using the actual market prices of the constituent securities.

entry.title: CFA0162-Q3

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The first decision is identifying the target market that the index is intended to represent because the target market determines the investment universe and the securities available for inclusion in the index.

entry.itemBody: When creating a security market index, an index provider must first determine the:

entry.title: CFA0162-Q6

feedback.neutral: B is correct. The price return is the sum of the weighted returns of each security. The return of Able is 20 percent [(12 – 10)/10]; of Baker is –5 percent [(19 – 20)/20]; and of Charlie is 0 percent [(30 – 30)/30]. The price return index assigns a weight of 1/3 to each asset; therefore, the price return is 1/3 × [20% + (–5%) + 0%] = 5%.

entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information for an equal-weighted index comprised of assets Able, Baker, and Charlie:

Security Beginning of
Period Price (€)		 End of Period
Price (€)		 Total
Dividends (€)
Able 10.00 12.00 0.75
Baker 20.00 19.00 1.00
Charlie 30.00 30.00 2.00

 

The price return of the index is:

entry.title: CFA0162-Q7

feedback.neutral:
C is correct. The total return of an index is calculated on the basis of the change in price of the underlying securities plus the sum of income received or the sum of the weighted total returns of each security. The total return of Able is 27.5 percent; of Baker is 0 percent; and of Charlie is 6.7 percent:

  • Able: (12 – 10 + 0.75)/10 = 27.5%

  • Baker: (19 – 20 + 1)/20 = 0%

  • Charlie: (30 – 30 + 2)/30 = 6.7%

An equal-weighted index applies the same weight (1/3) to each security’s return; therefore, the total return = 1/3 × (27.5% + 0% + 6.7%) = 11.4%.

entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information for an equal-weighted index comprised of assets Able, Baker, and Charlie:

Security Beginning of
Period Price (€)		 End of Period
Price (€)		 Total
Dividends (€)
Able 10.00 12.00 0.75
Baker 20.00 19.00 1.00
Charlie 30.00 30.00 2.00

 

The total return of the index is:

entry.title: CFA0162-Q8

feedback.neutral:
B is correct. The price return of the price-weighted index is the percentage change in price of the index: (68 – 75)/75 = –9.33%.

Security Beginning of Period

Price (£) 		  End of Period

Price (£)
ABC   25.00     27.00
DEF   35.00     25.00
GHI   15.00     16.00
TOTAL   75.00     68.00

entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information for a price-weighted index comprised of securities ABC, DEF, and GHI:

Security Beginning of
Period Price (£)		 End of Period
Price (£)		 Total
Dividends (£)
ABC 25.00 27.00 1.00
DEF 35.00 25.00 1.50
GHI 15.00 16.00 1.00

 

The price return of the index is:

entry.title: CFA0162-Q9

feedback.neutral:
B is correct. The price return of the index is (48,250,000 – 53,750,000)/53,750,000 = –10.23%.

Security Beginning of Period Price (¥) Shares Outstanding Beginning of Period Value (¥) End of Period Price (¥) End of Period Value (¥)
MNO 2,500 5,000 12,500,000 2,700 13,500,000
QRS 3,500 7,500 26,250,000 2,500 18,750,000
XYZ 1,500 10,000 15,000,000 1,600 16,000,000
Total     53,750,000   48,250,000

entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information for a market-capitalization-weighted index comprised of securities MNO, QRS, and XYZ:

Security Beginning of
Period Price (¥)		 End of Period
Price (¥)		 Dividends
per Share (¥)		 Shares
Outstanding
MNO 2,500 2,700 100 5,000
QRS 3,500 2,500 150 7,500
XYZ 1,500 1,600 100 10,000

 

The price return of the index is:

entry.title: CFA0162-Q10

feedback.neutral:
B is correct. The total return of the market-capitalization-weighted index is calculated below:

Security Beginning of Period Value (¥)   End of Period Value (¥)   Total

Dividends (¥) 		  Total Return (%)
MNO 12,500,000   13,500,000   500,000   12.00
QRS 26,250,000   18,750,000   1,125,000   –24.29
XYZ 15,000,000   16,000,000   1,000,000   13.33
Total 53,750,000   48,250,000   2,625,000   –5.35

entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information for a market-capitalization-weighted index comprised of securities MNO, QRS, and XYZ:

Security Beginning of
Period Price (¥)		 End of Period
Price (¥)		 Dividends
Per Share (¥)		 Shares
Outstanding
MNO 2,500 2,700 100 5,000
QRS 3,500 2,500 150 7,500
XYZ 1,500 1,600 100 10,000

 

The total return of the index is:

entry.title: CFA0162-Q11

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The target market determines the investment universe and the securities available for inclusion in the index.

entry.itemBody: When creating a security market index, the target market:

choices.itemBody: B. is usually a broadly defined asset class.
C. determines the number of securities to be included in the index.

entry.title: CFA0162-Q12

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The sum of prices at the beginning of the period is 96; the sum at the end of the period is 100. Regardless of the divisor, the price return is 100/96 – 1 = 0.042 or 4.2 percent.

entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following data for a price-weighted index:

  Beginning of Period   End of Period
Security Price (€) Shares Outstanding   Price (€) Shares Outstanding
A 20.00 300   22.00 300
B 50.00 300   48.00 300
C 26.00 2,000   30.00 2,000

 

The price return of the index over the period is:

entry.title: CFA0162-Q13

feedback.neutral:
B is correct. It is the percentage change in the market value over the period:

  • Market value at beginning of period: (20 × 300) + (50 × 300) + (26 × 2,000) = 73,000

  • Market value at end of period: (22 × 300) + (48 × 300) + (30 × 2,000) = 81,000

  • Percentage change is 81,000/73,000 – 1 = 0.1096 or 11.0 percent with rounding.

entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following data for a value-weighted index:

  Beginning of Period   End of Period
Security Price (£) Shares Outstanding   Price (£) Shares Outstanding
A 20.00 300   22.00 300
B 50.00 300   48.00 300
C 26.00 2,000   30.00 2,000

 

The return on the value-weighted index over the period is:

entry.title: CFA0162-Q14

feedback.neutral:
C is correct. With an equal-weighted index, the same amount is invested in each security. Assuming $1,000 is invested in each of the three stocks, the index value is $3,000 at the beginning of the period and the following number of shares is purchased for each stock:

  • Security A: 50 shares

  • Security B: 20 shares

  • Security C: 38.46 shares.

Using the prices at the beginning of the period for each security, the index value at the end of the period is $3,213.8: ($22 × 50) + ($48 × 20) + ($30 × 38.46). The price return is $3,213.8/$3,000 – 1 = 7.1%.

entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following data for an equally-weighted index:

  Beginning of Period   End of Period
Security Price (¥) Shares Outstanding   Price (¥) Shares Outstanding
A 20.00 300   22.00 300
B 50.00 300   48.00 300
C 26.00 2,000   30.00 2,000

 

The return on the index over the period is:

entry.title: CFA0162-Q15

feedback.neutral: A is correct. In the price weighting method, the divisor must be adjusted so the index value immediately after the split is the same as the index value immediately prior to the split.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following index weighting methods requires an adjustment to the divisor after a stock split?

entry.title: CFA0162-Q16

feedback.neutral: C is correct. The main source of return differences arises from outperformance of small-cap securities or underperformance of large-cap securities. In an equal-weighted index, securities that constitute the largest fraction of the market are underrepresented and securities that constitute only a small fraction of the market are overrepresented. Thus, higher equal-weighted index returns will occur if the smaller-cap equities outperform the larger-cap equities.

entry.itemBody: If the price return of an equal-weighted index exceeds that of a market-capitalization-weighted index comprised of the same securities, the most likely explanation is:

entry.title: CFA0162-Q17

feedback.neutral: C is correct. “Float” is the number of shares available for public trading.

entry.itemBody: A float-adjusted market-capitalization-weighted index weights each of its constituent securities by its price and:

choices.itemBody: B. the number of its shares outstanding.
C. the number of its shares available to the investing public.

entry.title: CFA0162-Q18

feedback.neutral: B is correct. Fundamental weighting leads to indexes that have a value tilt.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following index weighting methods is most likely subject to a value tilt?

entry.title: CFA0162-Q19

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Rebalancing refers to adjusting the weights of constituent securities in an index to maintain consistency with the index’s weighting method.

entry.itemBody: Rebalancing an index is the process of periodically adjusting the constituent:

choices.itemBody: A. securities’ weights to optimize investment performance.
B. securities to maintain consistency with the target market.
C. securities’ weights to maintain consistency with the index’s weighting method.

entry.title: CFA0162-Q20

feedback.neutral: B is correct. Changing market prices will cause weights that were initially equal to become unequal, thus requiring rebalancing.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following index weighting methods requires the most frequent rebalancing?

entry.title: CFA0162-Q21

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Reconstitution is the process by which index providers review the constituent securities, re-apply the initial criteria for inclusion in the index, and select which securities to retain, remove, or add. Constituent securities that no longer meet the criteria are replaced with securities that do. Thus, reconstitution reduces the likelihood that the index includes securities that are not representative of the target market.

entry.itemBody: Reconstitution of a security market index reduces:

choices.itemBody: C. the likelihood that the index includes securities that are not representative of the target market.

entry.title: CFA0162-Q22

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Security market indexes play a critical role as proxies for asset classes in asset allocation models.

entry.itemBody: Security market indexes are used as:

choices.itemBody: B. proxies to measure unsystematic risk.
C. proxies for specific asset classes in asset allocation models.

entry.title: CFA0162-Q23

feedback.neutral: A is correct. Security market indexes are used as proxies for measuring market or systematic risk, not as measures of systemic risk.

entry.itemBody: Uses of market indexes do not include serving as a:

choices.itemBody: B. basis for new investment products.
C. benchmark for evaluating portfolio performance.

entry.title: CFA0162-Q24

feedback.neutral: B is correct. Sector indexes provide a means to determine whether a portfolio manager is more successful at stock selection or sector allocation.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements regarding sector indexes is most accurate? Sector indexes:

choices.itemBody: A. track different economic sectors and cannot be aggregated to represent the equivalent of a broad market index.
B. provide a means to determine whether an active investment manager is more successful at stock selection or sector allocation.
C. apply a universally agreed upon sector classification system to identify the constituent securities of specific economic sectors, such as consumer goods, energy, finance, health care.

entry.title: CFA0162-Q25

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Style indexes represent groups of securities classified according to market capitalization, value, growth, or a combination of these characteristics.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following is an example of a style index? An index based on:

entry.title: CFA0162-Q26

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The large number of fixed-income securities—combined with the lack of liquidity of some securities—makes it costly and difficult for investors to replicate fixed-income indexes.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements regarding fixed-income indexes is most accurate?

choices.itemBody: A. Liquidity issues make it difficult for investors to easily replicate fixed-income indexes.
B. Rebalancing and reconstitution are the only sources of turnover in fixed-income indexes.
C. Fixed-income indexes representing the same target market hold similar numbers of bonds.

entry.title: CFA0162-Q27

feedback.neutral: C is correct. An aggregate fixed-income index can be subdivided by market sector (government, government agency, collateralized, corporate), style (maturity, credit quality), economic sector, or some other characteristic to create more narrowly defined indexes.

entry.itemBody: An aggregate fixed-income index:

choices.itemBody: A. comprises corporate and asset-backed securities.
B. represents the market of government-issued securities.
C. can be subdivided by market or economic sector to create more narrowly defined indexes.

entry.title: CFA0162-Q28

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Coupon frequency is not a dimension on which fixed-income indexes are based.

entry.itemBody: Fixed-income indexes are least likely constructed on the basis of:

entry.title: CFA0162-Q34

feedback.neutral: C is correct. The fixed-income market has more issuers and securities than the equity market.

entry.itemBody: In comparison to equity indexes, the constituent securities of fixed-income indexes are:

choices.itemBody: C. drawn from a larger investment universe.

entry.title: CFA0162-Q29

feedback.neutral: A is correct. Commodity indexes consist of futures contracts on one or more commodities.

entry.itemBody: Commodity index values are based on:

choices.itemBody: B. the market price of the specific commodity.
C. the average market price of a basket of similar commodities.

entry.title: CFA0162-Q30

feedback.neutral: C is correct. The performance of commodity indexes can be quite different from that of the underlying commodities because the indexes consist of futures contracts on the commodities rather than the actual commodities.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements is most accurate?

choices.itemBody: A. Commodity indexes all share similar weighting methods.
B. Commodity indexes containing the same underlying commodities offer similar returns.
C. The performance of commodity indexes can be quite different from that of the underlying commodities.

entry.title: CFA0162-Q31

feedback.neutral: B is correct. It is not a real estate index category.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following is not a real estate index category?

entry.title: CFA0162-Q32

feedback.neutral: B is correct. Hedge funds are not required to report their performance to any party other than their investors. Therefore, each hedge fund decides to which database(s) it will report its performance. Thus, for a hedge fund index, constituents determine the index rather than index providers determining the constituents.

entry.itemBody: A unique feature of hedge fund indexes is that they:

choices.itemBody: B. are determined by the constituents of the index.
C. reflect the value of private rather than public investments.

entry.title: CFA0162-Q33

feedback.neutral: A is correct. Voluntary performance reporting may lead to survivorship bias, and poorer performing hedge funds will be less likely to report their performance.

entry.itemBody: The returns of hedge fund indexes are most likely:

choices.itemBody: C. similar across different index providers.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516021
entry.itemBody: For portfolio managers of passive funds, market indexes are least useful as:

answerFeedback.997d0bf6-0193-45f1-8819-e088616a39a7: Incorrect. Market indexes are used as model portfolios to develop new ETFs. The use is relevant to these portfolio managers as some emerging markets are not easily accessible for direct investments.
answerFeedback.eb5d6c8e-2457-4983-974f-1d9ad315085b: Correct. Market indexes are used as benchmarks for actively managed portfolios, which is not relevant to passively managed funds.
answerFeedback.ff138769-4545-4310-bab6-1f9524acf62b: Incorrect. Market indexes are used as proxies to measure systematic risk. The use is relevant to passively managed funds.

choices.itemBody: C. tools to develop exchange-traded funds for non-accessible markets.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516035
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements is least accurate with respect to fixed-income indexes?

answerFeedback.c070ff3f-976c-498c-85c8-e278d7d84716: Incorrect. The indexes are susceptible to turnover of the underlying securities because over time, fixed-income securities mature and issuers offer new securities to meet their financial needs.
answerFeedback.c3b091d2-b6a2-4eea-a9b8-74d4556c11b8: Incorrect. Many of the underlying securities in the index tend to be illiquid because fixed-income markets are predominantly dealer markets.
answerFeedback.dc586508-5b78-4b26-87b2-2931de07b180: Correct. Compared with equity indexes, the large number of fixed-income securities—combined with the lack of liquidity of some securities—has made it more costly and difficult for investors to replicate fixed-income indexes and duplicate their performance.

choices.itemBody: A. Many of the underlying securities in the index tend to be illiquid.
B. The indexes are susceptible to turnover of the underlying securities.
C. Compared with equity indexes, it is easier and less expensive to replicate fixed-income indexes.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516100
entry.itemBody: A portfolio of securities representing a given security market, market segment, or asset class is best described as a:

answerFeedback.14288149-1bd6-4c2c-bf72-af328461cbda: Incorrect. A security market index represents a given security market, market segment, or asset class. A benchmark is a comparison portfolio and is used to evaluate the performance of active portfolio managers.
answerFeedback.8461d775-93bd-496f-b425-58913112baf1: Incorrect. A total return index reflects not only the prices of the constituent securities but also the reinvestment of all income received since inception.
answerFeedback.9fd3af99-6cc2-47e6-8ae9-6fe4749bcb22: Correct. A security market index represents a given security market, market segment, or asset class and is normally constructed as portfolios of marketable securities.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516101
entry.itemBody: Which of the following decisions most likely occurs as part of the index management phase of constructing and managing an index?

answerFeedback.1ecfbd45-0c13-4fff-812b-8fc2069cc9b9: Incorrect. Choosing the method of weighting to be used in the index is part of the construction of an index process.
answerFeedback.2cd2ea15-e860-43c4-aaf6-6b5ad7db9ae2: Correct. One of the decisions that must be made during the management phase of constructing and managing an index is when to rebalance the index. Rebalancing is necessary to maintain the weight of each security consistent with the index’s weighting method.
answerFeedback.e3b14c55-aae9-4b33-8af9-efe55aaec022: Incorrect. Identifying which securities to use from the target market is part of deciding how to construct an index and not part of deciding how to manage it.

choices.itemBody: C. How to identify which securities should be selected from the target market

entry.title: ITEM_20170516113
entry.itemBody: Which of the following most accurately describes the basis for construction of nearly all bond market indexes?

answerFeedback.666ebc40-5767-41db-a658-004539315f33: Incorrect. Many fixed-income securities do not trade frequently. Though index providers may estimate the prices of constituent securities using prices of traded fixed-income securities with similar characteristics, fixed-income markets are predominantly dealer markets.
answerFeedback.7afadb03-5f53-4dd0-885c-2624aa5316ba: Correct. Firms (dealers) are assigned to specific securities and are responsible for creating liquid markets for those securities by purchasing and selling them from their inventory. In addition, many securities do not trade frequently and, as a result, are relatively illiquid. As a result, index providers must contact dealers to obtain current prices on constituent securities to update the index, or they must estimate the prices of constituent securities using the prices of traded fixed-income securities with similar characteristics.
answerFeedback.ba44032d-8aa9-4471-9873-26f55681011a: Incorrect. Fixed-income markets are predominantly dealer markets, and many securities do not trade frequently.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516111
entry.itemBody:
A price-weighted index series is composed of the following three stocks:
  Price before Split Price after Split
Stock End of Day 1 End of Day 2
X $10 $12
Y $20 $19
Z $60 $22

If stock Z completes a three-for-one split at the end of Day 1, the value of the index after the split (at the end of Day 2) is closest to:

answerFeedback.0fe69b64-972c-41db-b214-78696c83258f: Incorrect. It calculates the changes in prices and uses it to derive the new index.
answerFeedback.309f8e39-53a3-4990-a7a3-b293c375c035:
Correct. The value of the price-weighted index is determined by dividing the sum of the security values by the divisor, which is typically set at inception to equal the initial number of securities in the index. In the case of a stock split, the index provider must adjust the value of the divisor by dividing the sum of the constituent prices after the split by the value of the index before the split. This adjustment results in a new divisor that keeps the index value at the same level as before the split. The new divisor will then be used to calculate the index value after the split.

Index before the split = 10+20+60 3

= 30

New divisor, X: 30 = 10+20+20 X

X = 1.67

Index after the split = 12+19+22 1.67

= 31.7
answerFeedback.a41e6890-db5b-4833-88b4-643b66afacd3: Incorrect. It uses price after split to calculate the new divisor.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516125
entry.itemBody:
An equity index consists of three securities with market information as follows:
Security Shares Outstanding Price at Beginning of Period Price at End of Period Dividend per Share
A 5,000,000 $10.00 $9.50 $1.00
B 2,000,000 $20.00 $21.50 $0.80
C 1,500,000 $30.00 $33.00 $0.60

The price-weighted total return index is closest to:

answerFeedback.15638c39-7c21-4a73-8bbc-07ed01ad7f3c: Incorrect. It is the price-weighted index based on price changes only; it ignores dividends.
answerFeedback.46e1d8f9-a19f-402b-9b30-d37f866bbc3d:
Correct.

Calculation of Index and Return Based on Price-Weighted Method

Security Shares Outstanding BOP Price EOP Price Dividends per Share
A 5,000,000 $10.00 $9.50 $1.00
B 2,000,000 $20.00 $21.50 $0.80
C 1,500,000 $30.00 $33.00 $0.60
Total $60.00 $64.00 $2.40
Index value 20.00 21.33 0.80
Type of Index BOP Value EOP Value Return
Price return $20.00 $21.33 6.65%
Total return $20.00 $22.13 10.65%

BOP = Beginning of period; EOP = Ending of period
answerFeedback.6bd439af-1943-45ea-abee-822c9820c73e:
Incorrect. It is the return based on equal-weighted method.

Calculation of Index and Return Based on Equal-Weighted Method

Security BOP Price EOP Price Dividends per share Price Return (%) Total Return (%) Weight (33.3%) × Price Return (%) Weight (33.3%) × Total Return (%)
A 10.00 9.50 1.00 –5.00% 5.00% –1.67% 1.67%
B 20.00 21.50 0.80 7.50% 11.50% 2.50% 3.83%
C 30.00 33.00 0.60 10.00% 12.00% 3.33% 4.00%
Total           4.17% 9.50%

BOP = Beginning of period; EOP = Ending of period

entry.title: ITEM_20170516157
entry.itemBody: Which of the following types of indexes is most appropriate as a model portfolio for a consumer goods exchange-traded fund (ETF)?

answerFeedback.12e631d2-ea56-4285-9d05-f22b094cedb0: Incorrect. Fundamentally weighted indexes use measures such as book value, cash flow, revenues, earnings, dividends, number of employees or GDP of countries to weight the constituent securities. Securities of different sectors and styles could be included in the same fundamentally weighted index. Therefore, fundamentally weighted indexes do not serve as model portfolios for consumer goods ETFs.
answerFeedback.2387ef71-0991-478a-9f8e-43376fb91c4a: Correct. Sector indexes represent and track different economic sectors—such as consumer goods, energy, finance, health care, and technology—on a national, regional, or global basis. Sector indexes also serve as model portfolios for sector-specific ETFs (e.g., for a consumer goods ETF).
answerFeedback.6b66198c-c7c5-4130-9ee6-563b5f2c64d5: Incorrect. Style indexes represent groups of securities classified according to market capitalization, value, growth, or a combination of these characteristics, but do not represent economic sectors such as consumer goods. Therefore, style indexes do not serve as model portfolios for consumer goods ETFs.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516004
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements is most accurate with respect to rebalancing and reconstitution of security market indexes?

answerFeedback.299b8d0a-8954-481c-9714-695db9989eaf: Incorrect. Reconstitution is the process of changing constituent securities in the index; rebalancing refers to adjusting the weights of the constituent securities in the index. Turnover within an index results from both reconstitution and rebalancing.
answerFeedback.6d208aa9-dda8-4ce5-99ee-fa318e55d957: Incorrect. Price-weighted indexes are not rebalanced because the weight of each constituent security is determined by its price. For market-capitalization-weighted indexes, rebalancing is less of a concern and the weights are only adjusted to reflect mergers, acquisitions, liquidations, and other corporate actions between rebalancing dates.
answerFeedback.e0c52e8a-de7e-4388-855b-d098e6385b46: Correct. After an equal-weighted index is constructed and the prices of constituent securities change, the index is no longer equally weighted. Therefore, maintaining equal weights requires frequent adjustments (rebalancing) to the index.

choices.itemBody: B. Turnover within an index results from a reconstitution but not from rebalancing.
C. A price-weighted index requires rebalancing more than a market-capitalization-weighted index.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516011
entry.itemBody: The index weighting that results in portfolio weights shifting away from securities that have increased in relative value toward securities that have fallen in relative value whenever the portfolio is rebalanced is most accurately described as:

answerFeedback.2f933217-0dd5-46cb-b446-d0fa0b22dde8: Correct. Fundamentally weighted indexes generally will have a contrarian “effect” in that the portfolio weights will shift away from securities that have increased in relative value and toward securities that have fallen in relative value whenever the portfolio is rebalanced.
answerFeedback.460054db-7700-424f-9e3f-fcf7c0e9e76a: Incorrect. In an equal weighting scheme, securities that constitute the largest fraction of the target market value are underrepresented and securities that constitute a small fraction of the target market value are overrepresented. This weighting scheme does not consider fundamental measures in rebalancing.
answerFeedback.b958e082-bc95-47d8-9507-1d1f079883fc: Incorrect. In the float-adjusted market-capitalization weighting scheme, the constituent securities whose prices have risen the most (or fallen the most) have a greater (or lower) weight in the index.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516012
entry.itemBody:
A market index contains the following two securities:

Stock  Shares in Index Start-of-Period Price ($) End-of-Period Price ($) Dividend per Share ($)
A 600 40 37 2.00
B 500 50 52 1.50
The total return on an equal-weighted basis is closest to:

answerFeedback.522eaca0-5adb-4dfe-a4ae-0a7a222d0135:
Incorrect. It is the total return on price-weighted basis.

Stock Shares in index Start of Period Price ($) End of Period Price ($) Dividend per Share ($) Total Return (%) Start of Period Weight (%) Price-Weighted Total Return (%)
(1) (2) (3) (4) (5) = [(3) + (4)]/(2) – 1 (6) (5) × (6)
A 600 40 37 2 –2.50% 44% –1.11%
B 500 50 52 1.5 7.00% 56% 3.89%
Total return =[(–1.11 + 3.89)/2]       2.78%
answerFeedback.a0042632-4322-4968-8b9b-c10f9e9d10ad:
Incorrect. It is the price return on an equal-weighted basis.

Stock Shares in Index Start of Period Price ($) End of Period Price ($) Dividend per Share ($) Price Return (%)
(1) (2) (3) (4) = (3)/(2) – 1
A 600 40 37 2 –7.50%
B 500 50 52 1.5 4.00%
Total return =[(–7.5 + 4)/2]     –1.75%
answerFeedback.c4393ff9-f2bd-4442-afb8-c4789d671612:
Correct.

Stock Shares in Index Start-of- Period Price ($) End-of-Period Price ($) Dividend per Share ($) Price Return (%) Total Return (%)
(1) (2) (3) (4) = (3)/(2) – 1 = [(3) + (4)]/(2) – 1
A 600 40 37 2 –7.50% –2.50%
B 500 50 52 1.5 4.00% 7.00%
Total return = [(–2.5 + 7)/2]       2.25%

entry.title: ITEM_20170516036
entry.itemBody:
An investor gathers the following information for an index:

Value of the index as of 31 December 20X3 1,000
Interest income over the year 20X3 $23.50
Dividend income over the year 20X3 $21.50
Total return of the index over the year 20X3 –4.50%
The value of the index as of 1 January 20X3 is closest to:

answerFeedback.7693f9f5-431a-4af9-81ed-45edc1da9e01:
Correct. The total return of an index is the price appreciation, or change in the value of the price return index, plus income (dividends and/or interest) over the period, expressed as a percentage of the beginning value of the price return index. TRI = (VPRI1 − VPRI0 + IncI)/VPRI0 where

TRI = the total return of the index portfolio (as a decimal number)

VPRI1= the value of the price return index at the end of the period

VPRI0 = the value of the price return index at the beginning of the period

IncI = the total income (dividends and/or interest) from all securities in the index held over the period

–4.5% = (1000 – VPRI0 + 23.5 + 21.5)/VPRI0

VPRI0 = (1000 + 23.5 + 21.5)/(1 – 0.045) = 1,094
answerFeedback.7ffd8021-5ef3-40cb-898d-0715d51e5485: Incorrect. It simply considers change in the index and ignores dividend and interest income: 1,000/(1 – 0.045) = 1,047
answerFeedback.d3a6054e-3394-44dc-9df8-c35cd5f66423:
Incorrect. It does not take the interest income in the calculation:

–4.5% = (1,000 – VPRI0 + 21.5)/VPRI0

VPRI0 = (1,000 + 21.5)/(1 – 4.5%) = 1,070

entry.title: ITEM_20170516037
entry.itemBody:
A market index contains only the following three securities:

Security Beginning of Period Price per Share ($) Market Cap ($ millions)
X 100 100
Y 200 150
Z 110 300
Which approach to indexing will most likely give Security X a weight of 18%?

answerFeedback.55c17060-5d9a-47ed-a2e0-65866c94c937: Incorrect. Under the equal weighting method, each security will have one-third or 33.3% of the weight.
answerFeedback.66d355e2-f495-47f2-85f5-f9cb4c7e7efc:
Correct. As the following computations show, the market-capitalization approach to indexing will give Security X the lowest weight in the index.

Index Weighting Method Method of Computation Weight of Security X in the Index
Price 100/(100 + 200 + 110) = 0.244, or 24.4%
Equal 1/3 = 0.333, or 33.3%
Market cap 100/(100 + 150 + 300) = 0.182, or 18.2%
answerFeedback.f0164ca6-22bc-4cb9-8771-c97e6971ef79: Incorrect. Under the price weighting method, the weight of security X = 100/(100 + 200 + 110) = (100/410) = 0.244 = 24.4%.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516039
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is least likely to be directly reflected in the returns on a commodity index?

answerFeedback.58f66fa0-9a28-4135-b20a-7947cdbcea66: Incorrect. Changes in the futures prices of commodities in the index are reflected in the index.
answerFeedback.bee1dcab-4b56-4631-9b96-78ddec6f9e8b: Incorrect. The roll yield is reflected in the returns on a commodity index.
answerFeedback.c933ff30-3ec9-40b9-a040-bb512d883c31: Correct. Commodity index returns reflect the changes in future prices and the roll yield. Changes in the underlying commodity spot prices are not reflected in a commodity index.

choices.itemBody: B. Changes in the spot prices of underlying commodities
C. Changes in the futures prices of commodities in the index

entry.title: ITEM_20170516053
entry.itemBody: A security market index that reports returns based on the reinvestment of income and the change in price of its constituent securities is best described as which type of index?

answerFeedback.465a0676-58d0-4640-abba-bbc160cf5516: Correct. A total return index reflects not only the constituent securities’ prices but also the reinvestment of all income since inception.
answerFeedback.74386e28-8566-4430-af90-c94dfa7d27c0: Incorrect. Float-adjustment is related to the weighting of constituent securities within the index and is not related to whether the index is reported based on price return or total return.
answerFeedback.b23b01aa-c31f-4580-bcf3-4f410e1f3f54: Incorrect. A price index reflects only the prices of the constituent securities within the index and excludes the reinvestment of income.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516072
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements concerning different types of market indexes is least accurate?

answerFeedback.6a0ea204-cce6-468e-8ef9-8d250470b3b3: Incorrect. Commodity indexes do not have an obvious weighting mechanism, and index providers create their own weighting methods. As a result, commodity indexes are subject to different weighting methods for specific commodities.
answerFeedback.a2eaf67e-42fd-4b29-ad54-2c1122c88c03: Correct. The fixed-income universe includes securities issued by governments, government agencies, and corporations with a variety of types and characteristics. The number of fixed-income securities is many times larger than the number of equity securities.
answerFeedback.ff4b4c02-a3c3-4c06-908a-1ea071325cc4: Incorrect. Most research organizations rely on the voluntary cooperation of hedge funds to compile performance data. As a result, hedge fund indexes are subject to survivorship bias from voluntary reporting.

choices.itemBody: A. Hedge fund indexes are subject to survivorship bias from voluntary reporting.
B. Commodity indexes are subject to different weighting methods for specific commodities.
C. Equity indexes draw from a larger number of constituent securities than fixed-income indexes.

entry.title: ITEM_2019BEquity04JDB20U3
entry.itemBody: An equity index representing groups of securities classified on the basis of market capitalization is most likely a:

answerFeedback.4870c312-94e9-4c75-943a-0bc13edb5d26: Incorrect because multi-market indexes may represent multiple national markets, geographic regions, economic development groups, and, in some cases, the entire world.
answerFeedback.9bd1adab-38f1-4eca-b592-6811514481b8: Correct because style indexes represent groups of securities classified according to market capitalization, value, growth, or a combination of these characteristics. They are intended to reflect the investing styles of certain investors, such as the growth investor, value investor, or small-cap investor.
answerFeedback.d3fc3ee9-fea3-478c-b64e-d61b6dcabf0d: Incorrect because sector indexes represent and track different economic sectors—such as consumer goods, energy, finance health care, and technology—on either a national, regional, or global basis.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Equity-Chan-11
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about an equal-weighted index composed of three securities:

Security Beginning of Period Price (€) End of Period Price (€) Total Dividends (€)
A 20 18 1
B 10 15 3
C 15 21 0

The price return of the index is closest to:

answerFeedback.b4483593-5fa3-442c-9d21-ba5dbae4d4a5:
Incorrect because 38.33% is the total return [not price return] for an equal-weighted index.

• Total return for security A is ((End of Period Price + Dividend) / Beginning of Period Price)) –1 = (18+1)/20 – 1 = – 0.05 = – 5%.

• Price return for security B is ((End of Period Price + Dividend) / Beginning of Period Price)) –1 = (15+3)/10 – 1 = 0.8 = 80%

• Price return for security C is ((End of Period Price + Dividend) / Beginning of Period Price)) –1 = (21+0)/15 – 1 = 0.4 = 40%

• Equal weighting = average of the security's returns = (– 5% + 80% + 40%)/3 = 38.333% ≈ 38.33%.
answerFeedback.b9f8f5e4-85d7-43e7-912a-965edc070144:
Incorrect because 20% is the price return for a price-weighted index.

• Summation of end of period price for the three securities = (18+15+21) = 54.

• Summation of beginning of period price for the three securities = (20+10+15) = 45.

• Price return = (54/45) – 1 = 0.2 = 20%.
answerFeedback.c0dddd4d-f5b9-49dd-9600-6f605d519e92:
Correct because 26.67% is the price return for an equal-weighted index.

• Price return for security A is (End of Period Price / Beginning of Period Price) –1 = 18/20 – 1 = – 0.1 = – 10%.

• Price return for security B is (End of Period Price / Beginning of Period Price) –1 = 15/10 – 1 = 0.5 = 50%

• Price return for security C is (End of Period Price / Beginning of Period Price) –1 = 21/15 – 1 = 0.4 = 40%

• Equal weighting = average of the security's returns = (– 10% + 50% + 40%)/3 = 26.667% ≈ 26.67%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04012
entry.itemBody: Which of the following index weighting schemes most likely causes a bias in the index when high-priced stocks split?

answerFeedback.494dcfc2-c941-4223-8c84-cc44b71e4842: Correct because when a company's shares split, their price declines and their weight in a price-weighted index is reduced, regardless of the importance of the stock.
answerFeedback.613d45d8-db79-4cc0-8d29-fc54a455fa61: Incorrect because there is an automatic adjustment for stock splits and other capital changes in a value-weighted index.
answerFeedback.6558d517-5d40-4a8c-8af6-f8ff3ed75fe4: Incorrect because each stock's percentage price change has equal weight in an equal-weighted index, and a split has no influence on the result.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Equity-Crutu-03
entry.itemBody: If a stock index's constituents make no distributions to their shareholders, the total return of the index is:

answerFeedback.19f0c062-6c86-4035-ae86-89c292a820dc: Incorrect because a total return index reflects not only the prices of the constituent securities but also the reinvestment of all income received since inception. As the constituents securities received no income (e.g. dividends or other distributions), the value of the price version equals the value of the total return version of the index.
answerFeedback.492c402f-2950-46de-a550-bb373a530ec6: Correct because a total return index reflects not only the prices of the constituent securities but also the reinvestment of all income received since inception. As the constituents securities received no income (e.g. dividends or other distributions), the value of the price version equals the value of the total return version of the index.
answerFeedback.8610d2ef-c8be-4279-bc7c-d7afd97b1252: Incorrect because a total return index reflects not only the prices of the constituent securities but also the reinvestment of all income received since inception. As the constituents securities received no income (e.g. dividends or other distributions), the value of the price version equals the value of the total return version of the index.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05952
entry.itemBody: Which of the following indexes are regularly rebalanced by the index provider?

answerFeedback.1d4b7a40-6546-4f38-8518-34f3e88ce010: Incorrect because price-weighted indexes are not rebalanced because the weight of each constituent security is determined by its price.
answerFeedback.510cddac-c87b-43fe-ac5f-ddd46e8be878: Incorrect because price-weighted indexes are not rebalanced because the weight of each constituent security is determined by its price.
answerFeedback.6fae89f6-c4eb-44c8-afe2-318a8feef771: Correct because rebalancing is necessary because the weights of the constituent securities change as their market prices change. The weights of the securities in the equal-weighted index at the end of the period are no longer equal. Therefore equal-weighted indexes are regularly rebalanced.

choices.itemBody: C. Both price-weighted indexes and equal-weighted indexes

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02537
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a price-weighted index composed of three stocks:

Stock Outstanding Shares Beginning of Period Price Dividends per Share End of Period Price
1 10,000 $25.00 $2.00 $20.00
2 40,000 $10.00 $0.50 $13.50
3 50,000 $10.00 $0.00 $14.00

The index's price return is closest to:

answerFeedback.007b754b-c582-4cae-8d82-08149b2e3d4c:
Correct because it is the price return for the price-weighted index of the three stocks and is computed as follows:

The price return of an index is expressed as PRI = VPRI1-VPRI0VPRI0=VPRI1VPRI0-1

where:

VPRI1 = value of the price return index at the end of the period (EOP) = sum of prices at EOP

VPRI0 = value of the price return index at the beginning of the period (BOP) = sum of prices at BOP

Price return = (20.00 + 13.50 + 14.00) / (25.00 + 10.00 + 10.00) – 1 = (47.50/45.00 – 1) = 0.0556

= 5.56% ≈ 5.6%.
answerFeedback.b4a9601e-6d3f-4cab-8183-bc254ba54243:
Incorrect because it is the price return for a market-capitalization weighted index of the three stocks computed as follows:

Market-Cap price return = ∑ wi × (Pi1/Pi0)

where:

Pi1 = end-of-period price of the ith security

Pi0 = begin-of-period price of the ith security

Total portfolio market capitalization at beginning of period = 250 + 400 +500 = 1150

wi = fraction of the portfolio allocated to the ith security; w1 + w2 + w3 = 1.00

w1 = 250 / 1,150 = 0.2174, w2 = 400 / 1,150 = 0.3478, w3 = 500 / 1,150 = 0.4348.

Price return = 0.2174 × (–20%) + 0.3478 × (35%) + 0.4348 × (40%).

Price return = −4.348 + 12.174 + 17.391 = 25.22% ≈ 25.2%.
answerFeedback.f29d743f-eeb5-4274-8889-7ec0d8c0cccc:
Incorrect because it is the total return for a price-weighted index of the three stocks computed as follows:

The total return for the index is expressed as TRI = VPRI1- VPRI0+IncIVPRI0, where

IncI = the total income (dividends and/or interest) from all securities in the index held over the period.

Total return = (20.00 +2.00 + 13.50 +0.50 + 14.00 + 0.00) / (25.00 + 10.00 + 10.00) – 1

= (50.00 / 45.00) – 1 = 0.1111 = 11.11% ≈ 11.1%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03285
entry.itemBody: The index weighting method that underrepresents securities that constitute the largest fraction of the target market value is most likely the:

answerFeedback.2bf253b1-962e-4b11-b617-334ba329cda4: Correct because a disadvantage of an equal-weighted index is that securities that constitute the largest fraction of the target market value are underrepresented, and securities that constitute a small fraction of the target market value are overrepresented.
answerFeedback.6a5198ec-854a-4787-85ee-7c5967d9e2de: Incorrect because the value of the price-weighted index is determined by dividing the sum of the security values by the divisor, which is typically set at inception to equal the initial number of securities in the index. The constituent that has the highest price, also has the highest weighting and thus will have the greatest impact on the return of the index. All else being equal, this weighting method would not underrepresent securities that constitute the largest fraction of the target market. The main disadvantage of price weighting is that it results in arbitrary weights for each security. In particular, a stock split in any one security causes arbitrary changes in the weights of all the constituents' securities. A stock split on a security that represents the largest fraction of the target market (pre-split) could cause it to be underrepresented (post-split), but such occurrences are random. Moreover, the weighting method does not determine which constituents, large or small, will split their stock price.
answerFeedback.f43c76a9-6697-40c0-9995-c8e2a23c82e7: Incorrect because the primary advantage of market-capitalization-weighting is that constituent securities are held in proportion to their value in the target market.
